key_facts: An IPBES report warns against addressing global crises in isolation.
Siloed governance leads to ineffective and harmful outcomes.
The report urges a holistic approach to climate, biodiversity, food, health, and water.
Over 70 low-cost integrated solutions are identified.
Short-term financial priorities often ignore environmental costs.
A health and biodiversity project in Senegal shows benefits of integrated strategies.
More than half the global population is impacted by environmental degradation.
Developing countries are especially affected by environmental decline.
'Business as usual' scenarios predict worsening biodiversity, water, and health conditions.
Sustainable practices can offer co-benefits across multiple sectors.
